goal.ch: In modern terms, this course should be named Condensed Matter Physics I. It aims to equip graduate students (or senior undergraduates) with an in-depth understanding of the properties and behaviors of crystalline solids through the use of quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics.
goal.en: In modern terms, this course should be named Condensed Matter Physics I. It aims to equip graduate students (or senior undergraduates) with an in-depth understanding of the properties and behaviors of crystalline solids through the use of quantum mechanics and statistical mechanics.

outline.ch:
Free electron gas model of metals, crystal structure, band theory, dynamics of Bloch electrons and measurement of band structure, lattice vibrations, semiclassical transport theory.
If time permits: semiconductors, magnetism, topological phases, interacting electrons, superconductivity.
Prerequisites: Graduate Quantum Mechanics I (which can be taken concurrently); familiarity with Graduate Statistical Mechanics I is preferred but not required; knowledge of undergraduate solid state physics is helpful but not essential.
--------------------------------------------
Useful graduate-level references:
1. Solid State Physics, N. W. Ashcroft and N. D. Mermin, Cengage Learning (1976).
2. Introduction to Condensed Matter Physics: Volume 1, D. Feng and G. Jin, World Scientific (2005).
3. Solid-State Physics: An Introduction to Principles of Materials Science, H. Ibach and H. Lüth, Springer (2009) [eBook ISBN: 9783540938040].
4. Condensed Matter Physics (Second Edition), M. P. Marder, Wiley (2010).
5. Solid State Physics, G. Grosso and G. P. Parravicini, Academic Press (2013) [eBook ISBN: 9780123850300].
6. Fundamentals of Condensed Matter Physics, M. L. Cohen and S. G. Louie, Cambridge University Press (2016).
7. Solid-State Physics: Introduction to the Theory, J. Patterson and B. Bailey, Springer (2018) [eBook ISBN: 9783319753225].
8. Modern Condensed Matter Physics, S. M. Girvin and K. Yang, Cambridge University Press (2019).
9. Quantum Theory of Materials, E. Kaxiras and J. D. Joannopoulos, Cambridge University Press (2019).
10. Band Theory and Electronic Properties of Solids, J. Singleton, Oxford University Press (2001).
11. Advanced Quantum Condensed Matter Physics: One-Body, Many-Body, and Topological Perspectives, M. El-Batanouny, Cambridge University Press (2020).
12. Fundamentals of the Physics of Solids, Volume 2: Electronic Properties, J. Solyom, Springer (2009) [eBook ISBN: 9783540853169].
Useful undergraduate-level references:
13. The Oxford Solid State Basics, S. H. Simon, Oxford University Press (2013) [see also the online lectures recording at Oxford: https://podcasts.ox.ac.uk/series/oxford-solid-state-basics].
14. Introduction to Solid State Physics, C. Kittel, Wiley (2018).
15. Lectures on Solid State Physics, D. Tong, http://www.damtp.cam.ac.uk/user/tong/solidstate.html

textbook.ch: We will follow the main line presented in Ashcroft and Mermin, considered a bible in solid state physics, occasionally supplementing it with modern perspectives from other references.
